Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in determining the applicant's residency days under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant provided inconsistent evidence regarding days absent (194 vs. 33 days) and lacked credible documentation to support physical presence in Canada
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge’s decision
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge’s decision was reasonable
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Citizenship Judge in residency calculation
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of evidence, consistency of declarations
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative decision
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence deemed unreliable due to inconsistencies
Evidence_Used: Applicant's declarations on residency, absence records
Application_Basis: Requirement of at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Inconsistent reports of days absent, lack of supporting documents
Governing_Rule: Applicant must prove 1,095 days of physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent evidence and lack of credible documentation
Cause_Description: Inconsistent declarations and lack of credible evidence regarding residency days
Evidence_Handling: Discrepancies in evidence led to rejection of applicant's claims
Evidence_Issues: Inconsistencies in reported absences, insufficient proof of presence
Evidence_Assessment: Unreliable due to contradictions and lack of corroboration
Decision_Rationale: Judge’s finding of unreasonable credibility was supported by record
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Contradictory data on days absent, inadequate documentation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law
